text: hi Brian Dempsey here and wanted to make
a quick video to address a couple of
things that came up in a discussion on
Facebook about reading and becoming a
better reader and so as we kind of went
through this thread online we were
sharing some tips and ideas about how to
improve our reading comprehension and so
I thought I would share a few things
that I do and maybe this will be a help
to you number one when you read a book
and by the way we will title this video
ten tips to improve your reading
comprehension and so number one is from
Benjamin Franklin himself and what he
said was never read a book without a pin
in your hand and so boy I take that to
heart
I hardly walk to a mailbox without
having a book and a pin and so if you
have a pin in your hand
no matter what no matter what you're
reading you have the opportunity to
underline highlight personally I like to
scribble circle argue with the author if
you read in the in the columns of my
books sometimes I'll write boy that's a
great point or you're a bloomin idiot or
whatever but I really interact with the
author as I write in books and some
people I know it makes your skin crawl
- just think of writing in a book but if
you want to improve your reading
comprehension the very first thing that
I would do is take Benjamin Franklin's
advice and never read a book without a
pen in your hand another thing when
we're talking about reading
comprehension
number two is read a whole paragraph or
a whole section before you go to
highlight or underline something I know
sometimes I kind of get ahead of myself
and I'll be reading through a book and
most of the kinds of books that I read
are not they're not novels they're not
fiction books and so they're they're a
little bit more technical or oriented
for study so so sometimes we will begin
and the very first line that you see
that's interesting you'll want to
highlight that and what I found is if
you read the entire paragraph first a
lot of times there may be a summary
statement or there may be a a little
better information for you to highlight
down in the paragraph rather than just
breaking up your train of thought so you
may want to read a whole section first
and then go back and find what you want
to highlight and I think that will help
with some reading comprehension another
thing that I do in fact I do it a lot is
I read out loud and if you read out loud
you will read more slowly than if you
read silently but there are times where
by reading out loud by reading with
inflection you're able to to have more
senses engaged in what you're reading so
you're not just seeing it but you're
also hearing what you're reading and
that simply helps with reading
comprehension as well and by the way I
read a study just today about reading
out loud and the study gave some great
insights one of the things that it
mentioned was if people read a list you
know like a list of items and one of
those items was different than the rest
maybe there was a list of ten things and
it was ten kinds of birds and one or
nine kinds of birds and one was a sport
people would tend to remember the sport
and they would forget the other nine and
so what it shows us is those things that
stand out those things that are somehow
different tend to make a more of an
impression in our brain so a lot of
times what I'll do is if I'm reading and
I come across a paragraph that you know
it's just really solid something I
really want to get I'll stop and I'll
read that out loud and it really helps
to set it apart in my thinking so so
there are times where you can read out
loud so never read a book or yeah never
read a book without a pin in your hand
read a whole paragraph or section before
you go through and highlight or
underline at
time's read out loud and then also read
silently you know if we're going to read
out loud sometimes sometimes we want to
read silently and I would encourage you
if you do this when we're talking about
reading comprehension read with a pencil
read with a pen and simply check you
know as you see something that stands
out you see something interesting simply
put a little check in the margin and
that way you can keep reading this gives
you the big picture of a book and then
you can go back through and look and pay
attention later to some of the things
that you you checked but that will help
improve your comprehension this next one
I think is something a lot of people
just don't do and when you're you're
reading to study when you're reading and
it's something that you really want to
comprehend it's not just enjoyment
something that I do often in fact it
probably makes me look pretty silly for
somebody looking in my office or maybe
if I'm driving down the road but if I
read something I'll stop at the end of
the paragraph or at the end of the
section and I'll think through it in my
mind and sometimes I'll even talk
through it out loud as if I'm explaining
what I've read to someone if you can
formulate your thinking enough to be
able to communicate that to someone else
then it's just going to increase your
comprehension and if you do that
throughout the book if you do that
throughout your study it's it's going to
help significantly significantly so so
never read a book without a pen in your
hand read the whole paragraph first at
times read out loud
other times read silently and simply
check things that are important explain
what you read and then um this comes
from a chapter in a book that I'm going
to recommend here in just a moment but
learn to x-ray a book when we're talking
about reading comprehension I recognize
that it's okay not to read the entire
book in fact there are lots of books
that I buy that I skim through the table
of contents I look at the things that
the
are going to be important to me
especially if it's a compilation and and
I pick and choose the the sections of
the book that I'm going to read and it
took me a while to not feel guilty about
not reading the whole book and only
reading parts of it but by doing that by
being more selective I was able to
benefit much more than if I simply
laboured through some things that
presented information that at the time I
just wasn't interested in so learn to
pay attention to the table of contents
and really pick out the areas that you
want to read also something that that I
tend to do is pay attention to summary
words and summary words are things like
therefore or as a result or in
conclusion and make sure that when you
see that you are able in your mind to
know what his argument was what the
author's argument was before he got to a
summary because if you see a summary
word and you don't understand the
previous argument then you're not really
comprehending that so I usually mark
those kind of summary words I'll
underline them and I'll go back and make
sure that I know what the points are
that are leading up to the author's
conclusion and sometimes we find that
you know he's made some kind of logical
fallacy and really the points that he's
brought forth can lead to other
conclusions or maybe it's it's simply
not conclusive also something that I
would encourage you to do is use
highlighters or circle and underline key
phrases in a book I'll tell you I do
that here here's an example of a book
that I read just this past week and you
can see that what I highlight and then
you know I was reading and this
particular book is on pluralism and so
right here is the word tolerance and
then I will underline the key phrases or
the
words within a sentence and that really
helps to to stand out and it also helps
when I highlight my underline when I
finish a book before I simply put it
down and move on to the next thing I
typically pick it back up and go page
for page and just flip back through it
and I will read what I've highlighted I
just don't understand folks personally
who can read a book and they they don't
mark in it they don't write in it and
then you know maybe the one key fault or
maybe one thing that really stood out
it's simply lost in there two or three
or four hundred page book and they can't
open it up and go back and find math and
so I would encourage you use a
highlighter and a pin also when it comes
to reading comprehension mark words that
you don't know this is something that is
is going to help increase your
vocabulary I recently read just an
absolutely outstanding book called the
professor and the madman and if you can
see the subtitle here the subtitle is a
tale of murder insanity and the making
of the oxford english dictionary so it
is a book about the making of the
dictionary so I wasn't too surprised
when there were 35 or 40 words in the
first you know however many chapters of
this book that I didn't know but I went
through and circled every single
solitary word that I didn't know and
when I was done because this is not on a
Kindle I simply went to dictionary.com
and spent spent a little bit of time and
looked up some of these words and have
added a couple of them to my vocabulary
a few of these are a little archaic but
anyway fantastic thing to do Circle
words that you don't know finally the
last tip is read this book how to read a

trowel Vandoren absolutely outs
and one of the things that this does is
it it helps you to be able to read
multiple works and to compare them it
has the tip about x-raying a book and
you know kind of understanding the
author's purpose and goal and being able
to evaluate a book to see if it's
something that you want to read to begin
with so let's just review those ten tips
real quick because I didn't number them
throughout number one never read a book
without a pen in your hand number two
read a whole paragraph before you go
through and highlight or underline
anything and that way you get the bigger
context ting sometimes can find the
conclusions at times when you need to
read out loud you'll read more slowly
but it will help you to remember that as
you engage your senses also read
silently and as you read silently simply
use a pencil and just check key
paragraphs that you want to go back and
read later explain what you read learn
to x-ray a book and realize that you
don't have to read every single chapter
pay attention to summary words therefore
as a result in conclusion circle and
underline key words and phrases and a
sentence or in a paragraph mark words
that you don't know and look them up
again if you have a click I do double
